text: The thing about Earth is that it's always changing, and when one thing is changing another thing is affected. The thing with climate change is that Earth is always changing and we're going to be greatly affected so we're preventing this change. We were so well adapted with what we already have that we can't be bothered to start all over again. This is also the reason why we are keeping our current wildlife away from extinction, it's because we're afraid of change. This also why when searching for life, we're only taking notice of planets that are similar to us since we can't imagine a world different from us. There are two things that we can do and one thing to do is be ready to adapt to change and evolve instead of sticking with the past and not learn. Though I think when we accept that things will change, we're also bound to be heavily affected, and might go extinct, and that's a good enough reason to prevent these changes from happening, which is why that would be our second option. In the end it's either we stick with our old ways out let go of the past and be ready to face change.

text:
In 1968 Paul R. Ehrlich published the "Population Bomb" .  It warned of catastrophe in the 1970s and 1980s because the earth's natural resources would not keep up with population growth.  At the time he wrote the book the earth's population was estimated at about 3.5 billion people.   Today we have an estimated 7.6 billion people and a growing middle class Asia which use to be very poor.  No catastrophe from population growth.  Ditto for global warming.

History tells us "Don't worry be happy".

text: And this is just the thing.. the relatively stable period in our climate over the past 10 000 years isn't going to go on forever.  Regardless of human inputs, the climate is always shifting toward periods of glaciation or, more rarely, shifting toward hot-house conditions.  Neither of these states is viable for civilisation as we know it.  So we can either somehow extend the pristine Holocene-like conditions indefinitely with massive geoengineering, OR we can do everything we can to eliminate our footprint and become a civilisation that adapts to a world that will periodically see much of the northern hemisphere covered in really thick ice sheets.  Is artificially maintaining the Holocene even viable for the long-term thrivability of life on Earth?  Is a super-adaptive and slimmed down civilisation that is able to withstand ice-ages even remotely possible?  Neither of these scenarios seem possible to me.

text:
We are witnessing the end of an era and the turmoil of creating a new era.  The old era was about getting and keeping, greed, accumulating money and power, about getting a bigger piece of the pie!  That system has worked very well until now.  It will not solve our most pressing problems because they cannot envision a future without the old system.

The new era is up to us, the generation that will make the decisions for the future of humankind.  It has taken us 4 billion years to get to this point, each one of us the product of successful adaptation, exploration, reproduction and proliferation.  It should be obvious that the old ways of thinking and doing will not get us to a sustainable world, a world that includes everyone and all other living beings, a world based on respect, even down to bacteria.

The permafrost is melting, thereby releasing massive amounts of methane, possibly doubling the amount of carbon in the atmosphere.  This is the most urgent matter needing our attention!

The single most potent thing we can do right now, today, is to eat meat and dairy products once a week (or less)!  Just this one act can reduce GHGs by 85%.  Watch the movie Cowspiracy.  The powers that be do not want us taking matters into our own hands.  When heart bypass surgery generates $50 billion in revenue per year, don't expect the medical establishment to come out for a whole food, plant based diet.  We can have a sane and wise future if we are willing to envision it and start creating it today.  We can promote each other's health, the health of our planet, the health of all the other beings we share this great planet with, and the health of our future by the choices that we make today!  

We need a meme that goes viral, a meme that moves us to take over our own lives and move toward the kind of future we want.

author: DivideByZero

text: Dude, "little" ice age. If you don't know what that is, google it. I'm not talking about the last major era of glaciation which ended c9600 b.c., but the little ice age, an era of comparatively minor cooling which lasted roughly 300 years and ended roughly between 1840 and 1860. The earth has been warming ever since, but carbon emissions cannot account for this warming because, pre 1950, industry simply did not emit enough carbon to make an appreciable difference in climate. Why do ice ages end? The answers are not clear, and if we don't why the earth started to warm naturally in the 19th century we can't possibly know the extent to which current warming is part of the same natural cycle. Look, I am not an ideologue and I'm not trying to pick a fight. I acknowledge that industry affects the climate and that the earth is warming. To what degree does industry affect climate compared to natural earth cycles beyond our control¬†is the golden question. If you have an answer I'd love to hear it, but "dude, don't you know when the ice age ended" is not that answer.
author: Kaddywompous

text: ¬†@Kaddywompous¬† The earth has been warmer than the little ice age ever since, but it certainly wasn't continuous warming. There have been several large dips since then.
author: DivideByZero

text: Actually it's been suggest by some (e.g Rudimann's "early anthropocene" idea) that humans have been altering the climate for millennia an these effects are evident when events (such as the bubonic plague) lowered human populations enough for forests to regrow and sink significant amounts of carbon.

text:
I always tell myself 'You are living in the craziest time in the known scope of human history right now'. And I think that's just starting to sink in. 
There is a crazy amount of interconnectivity which 4 million of 7 million people participate in daily, you have established governments that either do well to their citizens or screws them over like climate change deniers, we have created a force of materialism and have a whole other, equally strong force fighting against that. We have societal norms that are broken every generation and we have reached a point in human relationships, where you have para-relations where thousands to millions can love one person and one person can be a voice for them. We have created such strong infrastructure that we have made entire concrete jungles, fighting back nature when it tries to take back its place, like a blade of grass pushing through pavement. 
We have created a world where if it was destroyed in an instant by natural disasters, or slowly by climate change, the path to rebuild would be next to impossible. We have created a world that cannot afford to be destructed. 
So, when are we going to act and stop something that threatens the way of life we have built up now, with all the changing societal norms, governments, and interconnectivity? 
We already change so much as a global community. 
If something were to threaten us to change even more, what would we do?
I'm dead serious. And wary if anyone will take this seriously.

text: The problem with climate change is not that it is a myth, or a conspiracy perpetuating the belief in a myth. Climate change is very much real. The data is there. The problem is that the situation has so much nuance, and most individuals are so very little educated about empirical principles and what it means to use science in order to better understand our planet and how to fix problems. New data is surfacing everyday that contradicts yesterday's theories. New theories are created from that new data and the progression continues. Essentially, "stopping climate change" is a ridiculous endeavor if one understands even 1/10th of the factors that determine climate and the billion other factors that determine how that affects humans. A better pursuit is to set goals for cleaner air, sustainable energy, cleaner water, etc. Until every one on earth is a scientist, using the phrase "climate change" will always be meaningless rhetoric.

text:
Mr "Pladimir Vutin"  -  Blimate change WAS a naturally occurring phenomenom, but not anymore.......not this time. 

Over the last 8 glacial, inter-glacial cycles CO2, unaided by the burning of fossil fuels, fluctuated, in the ‚Äúnatural‚Äù carbon cycle, between 180 ppm and 280 ppm and this change of 100 ppm took between 20,000 to 50,000 years. 

When CO2 emissions from natural sources are balanced out by the CO2 that is naturally absorbed, global average temperature remains relatively constant and Earth enjoys a stable climate. 
.
This ‚Äújust right‚Äù amount of CO2 (280 ppm) kept the Earth's average global temperature in the ‚ÄúGoldilocks‚Äù zone (not to hot, not to cold) for over 12,000 years allowing a relatively stable, temperate, Mediterranean type climate, with regular river flow to develop.  This climate allowed for extensive farming and human-kind transitioned from hunter-gatherers to farmers, giving rise to civilization.

Earth's natural carbon cycle is a complex system of biological, chemical and physical processes operating in balance, whereby CO2 is sequestered in plants during the spring and summer growing season through photosynthesis and 'naturally' recycled back into the atmosphere through respiration and decomposing plants in the fall and winter. 

Then about 150 years ago, a new factor emerged that is having a huge effect on average global temperature (AGT). That new factor is the addition of more CO2 into a carbon cycle that nature had kept in balance over hundreds of thousands of years.  This extra CO2 comes from humans burning fossil fuels.

The CO2 level has now reached 408 ppm and is rising at the rate of 100 ppm in 31 years instead of 20,000 to 50,000 years.

According to the Geological Society, there is no known precedent in the history of the Earth for the rate at which we are now increasing the atmospheric level of CO2, from the burning fossil fuels. 

Earth's current level of CO2 at 408 ppm exceeds the atmospheric conditions of the Pliocene era (350 to 400 ppm of CO2), which ended about 2.6 million years ago. 

Pliocene average global temperatures (AGT) were only about 2 to 3 C warmer than pre-industrial temperatures (13.2 C). 

Those temperatures drove an intense hydrological cycle with extreme evaporation and precipitation.  This led to extensive rain forests, lush Savannah's (now occupied by deserts), small ice caps (about two-thirds of the present) and the sea level was about 25 meters higher than at present.

Life abounded during the Pliocene. But such conditions mean agriculture would not be possible. The tropical Pliocene had intense alternating downpours and heat waves.  

The regular river flow and temperate Mediterranean type climates we are accustomed to, which allow for extensive farming which gave rise to human civilization could not exist under those conditions.

After reviewing the latest climate science reports the Intergovernmental Panel of Climate Change (IPCC) has reported with 'high confidence' that without cutting greenhouse gas emissions, the world risks 'severe, pervasive and irreversible impacts for people and ecosystems'.   

Severe, Pervasive and Irreversible Impacts

When it comes to global warming, "effect" follows "cause" by 40 years.  The climate changes we are currently experiencing come as a result of the CO2 levels as they were in 1975. 

We are now vulnerable to a level of climate disruption that human civilization has simply never seen before. 

We won't get a do-over on this.

text:
YourMajesty143 Okay, about the ocean, exploiting and burning fossil fuels causes a ton more damage, 60% of carbon footprint is caused by the burning of fossil fuels and these CO2 are being absorbed by the sea which is one of our largest carbon stores, this acidifies the ocean, causing any animal that forms shells as a protective mechanism to be threathened as the acidic water would erode away at their calcium carbonate structures. And let's not mention corals, they are extremely sensitive to temperature change and the pH value if the water, there's been massive coral bleaching due to increasing acidity and temperature in oceans, take a look at the Great Barrier Reef. 

Fish pellets? In the US anyway, most cattle feed is composed of mainly soybeans and corn. Anyway the dying off of corals is the larger cause of oceanic wildlife going extinct as they are the biodiversity hotspots in the seas.

Pollution? The mining and extracting of fossil fuels alone is devastating, heard of oil spills? They destroy the surrounding environment and kill off almost all the flora and fauna living there, if humans don't intervene by rescuing and washing off the oil on all the animals they will die in a matter of days. O and burning of fossil fuels both by cars and factories is the number 1 source for causing air pollution in all the cities and industrial area in the world. The air pollution alone causes an estimated 6.5 million people to die prematurely because of respiratory diseases and disorders alone annually.
 
Climate change caused by global warming ironically affects vulnerable developing countries that have much lesser carbon footprints than the industrious nations of Europe, North America and East Asia. These countries could face their weather patterns shifting into more radical patterns like more droughts and floods, especially those in Africa and South Asia, their crops rely hugely on the monsoons and people will face famine when there is inadequate water or their fields are flooded. Their mountain glaciers in South Asia that regulates the flow of water into their major rivers could also disappear as the global temperature rises, also affecting their water supply. 

The increasing rate of sea ice melting in the Artic could flood tiny island nations that had nothing to do with causing global warming. 

Yes yes I do agree that large scale unethical animal husbandry breeds diseases and the indiscriminate use of antibiotics also increases the risk of spawning superbugs. Also the deforestation of the Amazon rainforest is mostly due to make way for cattle farms, I'm not saying vegan is bad. I'm just saying humans should not just settle for veganism to combat climate change, I'm just saying the main cause of the problem is relying on fossil fuels and humans should never lose focus on curbing  non-renewables.

to climate change. In principle, observations of the climate response
to a single factor could directly show the impact of that factor, or climate
models could be used to study the impact of any single factor.
In practice, however, it is usually difficult to find measurements that
are influenced by only a single cause, and it is computationally prohibitive
to simulate the response to every individual factor of interest"

If that's not admission of falsification or just taking eachother's word, I have no idea what is.

Ooh, here's a few other quotes that I happen to like (from Chapter 4):
"There is medium evidence and high agreement that long-term trends in normalized losses have not been attributed to natural or anthropogenic climate change"
"The statement about the absence of trends in impacts attributable to natural or anthropogenic climate change holds for tropical and extratropical storms and tornados"
"The absence of an attributable climate change signal in losses also holds for flood losses"

Hilarious. Right? They're even admitting in their own published scientific findings that everything they believe is bullshit. I love it.

So please, keep trying to prove me wrong. You'll only end up failing.
author: Karkenou

text:
¬†@Karkenou¬†¬†The report is a summary intended for policy makers and the general population, so it doesn't include the methodology for every single measurement made. If you want that, you can go to specific studies that are linked to every claim made in the document.

Or what do you want, the raw satellite data? A table with every single of thousands of measurements made? These usually don't get published, because it's useless to the average person, but if you contact the people doing the research you're interested in, they might send it to you.

"How the fuck are they even able to measure that? And what the fuck is 'perturbation'? So now you're telling me that they're able to measure how sick the earth is?"

The RF of a gas is defined as the difference between incoming solar radiation and outgoing infrared radiation caused by the increased concentration of that gas. We have satellites with infrared cameras pointing at every square mile of the planet, it's not that hard to measure.

I'm not going to respond to everything, because the methodology for all the claims made in the report can be easily looked up.

text: ¬†@Robert Sims¬†¬†Well, ok, I might have gone too far with the 'nothing to do' part. Yes, the carbon isotope used in radiometric dating is created in the atmosphere. But it's source is cosmic rays hitting the upper atmosphere layers, so it's not really affected by any climate changes. If anything, changes in the Earth's magnetic field or solar activity could affect radiocarbon production, but you can still calibrate the normal carbon/radiocarbon ratio by studying tree rings.

text:
As long as we're talking about timelines, and how short of an amount of time we've been on the planet, and how its even shorter that we've been using fossil fuel...
...it should ALSO be noted that its been a VERY short amount of time that we've been able to actually physically monitor temperatures.
All other data, the data that goes back "tens of thousands" of years, is based off of ice core samples. Its literally "proxy" data, or a suggestion that we MIGHT know what the temperature was in a certain area of the planet only on certain days where the ice packed.  And from that.... we're trying to chart the temperature changes by fractions of a degree over millennia.
So as someone who loves science, I find it completely insulting when its suggested that we "know" what is happening on temperature trends over the ENTIRE planet by taking proxy measurements over millennia on one area of the planet, and extrapolating that as us knowing what happened all over the world.  Its further insulting that we literally change data from older weather instruments because we know that the data was flawed, but we presume to be able to "guess" how to correct that data.
And then there is the observation thing; that if you start observing anything from a fixed point in time, you'll be convinced that any trend you see is something important.  No matter if it happened before.

text:
It‚Äôs also about the extinction of certain species, some of which we rely on. Other than it really is about us. The planet will be fine, it always has been (Ice Age, volcanic period, etc.). Whether we‚Äôll be fine has always been the issue. As humans, we built our civilizations around bodies of water: the Nile, Tigris and Euphrates, the Amazon, the Mississippi and Colorado rivers, the Yangtze river and Indus Valley river not to mention every single coastline. Today most of the major cities in the world are near major bodies of water, even if it‚Äôs a lake or a river (i.e. the river Thames or Salt lake in Utah). They were made that way for good reasons too: partly for trade and partly for energy and agriculture (irrigation and water turbines). The only exception of a major city in America not near a body of water is Las Vegas which was built there by design due to the confluence of railway line intersections, Hoover dam workers, the Mafia and Mormons, ironically. Rising sea levels affect all of these things. People will have to move inland. Moreover, the droughts climate change has and will continue to create will dry up the lakes people rely on, Lake Chad in Africa being one of them, not to mention the changing weather patterns: more powerful hurricanes and typhoons, unpredictable weather patterns, various species extinctions. All of these combined lead to civil unrest and instability, especially in more vulnerable regions. That's why it‚Äôs such a complex problem that we have to deal with. 
All of the conservatives in every other country who are paid off by Oil, Coal and Natural Industries to deny it even exist and we‚Äôre the country that can have the greatest impact on combating it, especially if we ended oil subsidies and invested heavily in renewables like water and solar. If we did this, we could be exporting our products to the rest of the world, beating out China and establishing ourselves as an energy powerhouse (a Saudi Arabia of clean energy). But not as long as any meaningful action is blocked by the people bribed in Congress into believing it doesn‚Äôt exist and turning a blind eye its effects and the millions who follow them based on partly fear, partly on misunderstood religious religions (‚ÄúThere can‚Äôt be Global Warming because God promised never to destroy the world with a flood‚Äù as if anyone suggests the whole world would be submerged underwater or ‚ÄúJesus will come back in 50 years so why bother doing anything about it‚Äù, etc.). 
The fact of the matter is Climate Change exists whether you believe in it or not. It would be nice if it didn‚Äôt. It would be nice if polar bears weren‚Äôt really drowning, sea levels weren‚Äôt really rising, storms weren‚Äôt becoming more powerful, droughts becoming more frequent and severe and average global temperatures weren‚Äôt increasing. But that are and not believing it because it makes you feel uncomfortable or is an ‚Äúinconvenient truth‚Äù doesn‚Äôt change the fact that it exists. The fact of the matter is the truth doesn‚Äôt give a fuck about your feelings, it just is. So you either deal with an issue or you don‚Äôt, just know that not dealing with it will have significant consequences. Even the CIA and the Pentagon have acknowledged Climate Change and named it as a National Security threat for its potential to create civil unrest, internal displacement, and instability in various regions across the world, not to mention conflict over resources (water rights, etc.), destabilizing governments in the process and allowing for more radical extremes to take over. We have to deal with this. Some of the effects are here and unavoidable and will continue no matter what, but at this point we still have to mitigate them and prevent worse damage from occurring. We have an obligation to lessen the human suffering as much as we can.

text: No, the climate change issue isn't only about the vulnerability of human civilizations. It's also about biodiversity. Sure, life on earth may survive the current rapid rise of global temperature. (Or it might not--what's the guarantee that life will survive a mass extinction?) However, due to human activities, from direct habitat destruction and exploitation of species to the direct and indirect effects of human-induced climate change, life forms on earth are going extinct or are on the path to extinction in increasing proportion. Even if life on earth survives human-induced climate change, it will be depauperate compared to what humans have experienced until now, and the reduction in richness of species will be our fault. And this is a part of the climate change issue that matters to many of us.

text:
Looks like some of you guys misinterpreted the video. It doesn't mean that we shouldn't worry about climate change, nor we didn't cause the rise of  global temperature. The video just stating that the focus is wrong, we often said that "we need to save the earth", or "we're destroying the earth". No, we're not destroying the earth itself, it wont be destroyed.... that's why the campaign is (maybe) ineffective. But life on the earth IS in danger, not 100% of them obviously, but most of them, including human. So, this video is telling us that focus of climate change campaign should've been life, nature, and human.


EDIT: for people who (still) say it doesn't matter, it does, at least psychologically. When the campaign say "save the earth" most people feel skeptical because they know we can't destroy this enormous rock in the first place. But if the campaigns are saying to save human and other life on the earth, it'll make them care more about it.

text:
¬†@Dopamean otmic¬†
"Then what was it all for?"¬† I have a theory...

You know how the human brain has different segments? Well.. If you study enough biology, archaeology, evolutionary theory, etc, you'll eventually learn that each one of those segments came after (I would say as a result of) some major extinction event. The first event, known as snowball earth, forced mitochondria to merge with some other bacteria, thereby allowing multi-celled organisms to evolve. Since then, each extinction has cleared the way for progressively higher forms. And you can see that progression very clearly outlined in the structure of the human brain.

NOW...

Humankind has reached a paradox; wherein everything that has enabled us to evolve up to this point -- our viciousness, our cunning, our ability to beat plowshares into swords -- all come together to threaten the very future of this planet. And it does appear that the only way to move forward is by an act of LOGIC backed by a Political Will that the human animal simply is not capable of enduring, much less creating.

But the machine IS.

By the way, please add the following warming inputs to your "models" before crying wolf about human inputs.
1) The Sun. Seems to have been changing the temp. of Mars to the extent that the ice of Mars is melting to water, observed this year (2016) to be flowing. - Sorry no SUVs in Mars yet.
Venus - a weird planetary change to it's atmospheric composition seems to be taking place that requires high temp changes for the reactions.
Jupiter - Changes in it's spectra making it glow and develop huge storms being tracked as I write to you.
Saturn - Changes to spectra on the rings. Changes to it's perennial storm eye.
Other planetary changes to each planet from Mercury to Pluto in the Solar system all of which require higher energy inputs. 
As these can only be accounted for by a higher energy output from the Sun, it is logical that the Earth will also experience changes from the higher Sun output, unless you maintain that our planet is extraordinary and does not form part of this Solar system.
2) To whit, the Magnetic Poles have become highly peripatetic and moving far from their traditional positions. This means that the internal magma below the crust is moving.  A Thesis if that is true would be, extraordinary volcanic and earthquake activity on the surface. From Yellowstone to all around the Pacific Rim (Circle of Fire) there are continuous such reports in the last two years. Ergo we have a problem under our feet and not due to SUVs.
Observation: Summers and Autumns are becoming longer? The Inuits report the Sun does not rise and fall at the same place as traditionally. That means that the angle of the True North/South rotational axis of Earth may also have changed inclination in relation to the plane of Earth's elliptic around the Sun resulting in a higher surface exposure to the Sun, thus beginning climate changes on the surface of the whole planet changing the lines of the Tropics etc. Nothing to do with SUVs again. Sorry.
One last one before I leave. There are reports that corrals of the Great Barrier Reef of Australia are dying. The "warmists" point at this as proof of planet warming. However it is well known that coral does very well in warmer waters (No die offs around higher latitudes) and dies off in cooler waters. In fact the opposite of the B/S  they're selling us. Now couple this to the fact that the South Magnetic Pole is slowly moving towards the Australian side of Antarctica and the question begins to beg "is it just possible that the Great Barrier Reef current passing the Eastern Australian continent contains more cold water than was traditional?" If true again sorry no SUVs to blame here but correlative inputs for huge climate changes in the offing are true. But sorry WE ARE NOT RESPONSIBLE. STOP FEELING GUILTY. 
Best figure out what changes may happen from all the above, and change your habitat in order to survive. Good luck.

text:
Scarecrow22 - About the "Artificial Leaf" you mentioned.  

In 2011, Daniel Nocera and his research team announced the creation of the first practical artificial leaf described as an advanced solar cell the size of a poker card capable of splitting water into oxygen and hydrogen.  

In May 2012, Sun Catalytix, the startup based on Nocera's research, stated that it will not be scaling up the prototype as the device offers few savings over other ways to make hydrogen. 

Research into solar fuel production through artificial photosynthesis continues but in all cases to date the overall cost is not yet advantageous enough to compete with fossil fuels as a commercially viable source of energy.  So......Problem NOT solved

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_photosynthesis
author: Xander Bekkett

text:
So, "beachballa93" -  I read the entire article you supplied a link to and found many of his conclusions to be inaccurate or misleading.  The article contained a list of most, if not all of the debunked climate change denial arguments from long ago found on other denier blogs.

Towards the end the author admits: ‚ÄúIt should be very easy for the reader to tell from this document that I have a very strong bias against the actions of government to adapt the planet to the ACC Hypothesis‚Äù.  

He says: ‚ÄúI'm frequently asked "but what if you are wrong; isn't doing something better than doing nothing?"  This is a fair question.  I've been wrong before.  I'll be wrong again‚Äù.  

I found this answer to be rather cavalier.  There is a huge difference between playing roulette and playing ‚ÄúRussian‚Äù Roulette with a loaded gun, the stakes are much higher, which the author trivialises.

I did find his article to be detailed and very well written.  What I didn't find was any links to actual scientific evidence to support his opinions.  

While he sometimes refers to actual authentic scientific evidence, he then takes issue with the scientific conclusions of those published, peer reviewed articles and offers us nothing but his unscientific, unsupported opinion.  

Most of his article contains discussion on engineering matters that have absolutely no relevance to climate science although he claims they do.  

It should be noted that he is not a climate scientist and has never submitted this article of his for publication in any scientific journal for peer review.  

One wonders why until you notice that the author of this article, David Simpson, is an Oil & Gas Engineering Consultant who among other things, can address issues in Coalbed Methane, Low Pressure Operations, Gas Measurement and Oil Field Construction.  

His company web-site states:  If you have a problem with collecting, moving, or storing hydrocarbon products MuleShoe Engineering can help.  

He makes his living from work in the oil industry.  Now I understand his admitted bias.  What I can't understand is why this isn't clear to you. 

.

On a similar vein some of the predicted things that had not happened by 2014 when the article was written have happened.  But I would like an article that would do a better job of explaining how they know for sure and explaining some of the concerns.  

One that was not exactly split out but was within some in that article, that I also wonder about, was about the degree of variance in the results.  How did the decide on a conclusion when many of the methods seem like they should have a high probability of variance?  

Using a history reference as an example of what I mean: With carbon dating there is a range of 5,000 years(made up number not sure what the actual number is)  such as 2,000-7,000 years ago.  They have proven by carbon dating scrolls with dates on them, that the older number is more likely accurate.  How was the temperature variance settled?

You seemed like someone who was willing to help direct people to information that might help make sense of this issue.  I think a lot of people do not have the necessary knowledge to make up their own mind about global warming and thus have to rely on a opinion they trust.  I think this is a reason why there is so much confusion and division on the topic.  I wish there were more people out there who actually tried to help explain instead of just writing it off as dumb people who will not change their minds.

author: PACKO

text: This kind of mentality is arrogant and dangerous for society. One thing most people don't understand is that global climate change does not equal global warming. The world could experience years, even decades, of record low temperatures yet it could STILL be getting warmer. This because the Earth experiences a self-regulating mechanism that constantly fluctuates global temperatures, which can result in dramatic temperature changes in certain areas and certain times. The problem we are currently facing is that fluctuations in global temperatures have become more erratic and devastating, which could also lead to dramatic weather patterns, all of which is happening at a much faster pace that normal. And coincidentally, this changes can be traced to about the same time our society began to produce large amounts of pollution and greenhouse gasses, of which we are just beginning to comprehend it affects. And to complicate this topic even more, scientists have detected changing solar temperatures which are contributing to Earth's changing climate and temperature. While I don't believe that such epic event will even occur under any circumstance, movies like "The Day After Tomorrow" perfectly illustrate that changing global temperatures are capable of changing our society for ever.

text: +Kyle Stamps Most mass extinctions have serious abrupt climate change elements to them, and I'm glad to see you're familiar with the idea of them if not the causes, the biggest though The Great Dying aka the Permian-Triassic Extinction, caused by either volcanism or an impact which managed to ignite a huge coal reservoir in what would become Siberia "¬†with up to 96% of all¬†marine¬†species[5][6]¬†and 70% of¬†terrestrial¬†vertebrate¬†species becoming¬†extinct.[7]¬†It is the only known mass extinction of¬†insects.[8][9]¬†Some 57% of all families and 83% of all¬†genera¬†became extinct." That would be what I'm referring to. Humans did not cause it but it was caused by the sudden release of a huge amount of CO2 via the burning of fossil fuels, which then lead to a subsequent release of oceanic methane. So fairly analogous to what we're looking at in our instance.
